CAPTION FIG1.png: 'Figure 1: An assembling endocytic actin patch exerts strong squeezing forces at its base of an initial invagination. (A) Example of distribution of orthogonal forces in an (_r_, _z_-section of a nascent invagination adapted from simulation results in Figure 5A of Nickaeen et al. (2019). (B) Time dependence of squeezing force acting on the 2 nm wide portion at the base of the nascent tubule in (A), from a simulation described in Figure 5A of Nickaeen et al. (2019). The force of 320 pN applied to a 2 nm-wide band with the radius of 30 nm amounts to additional pressure of \\(\\sim 8.5\\) atm. (C) Cartoon of a head-neck (flasklike) shape with radii \\(r_{\\rm neck}\\) and \\(R_{\\rm head}\\); since turger pressure \\(P\\) is isotropic, \\(f_{\\rm heart}\\) for this shape diminishes to \\(\\pi r_{\\rm neck}^{2}P\\). (D) Graph of \\(f_{\\rm result}\\) (t) normalized to \\(f_{\\rm result}^{\\rm max}=\\pi R_{\\rm head}^{2}P\\) [dots, _A_(t) is the cross-action area at the base, see the text] is well approximated by function \\(\\{1+\\exp[(t-t_{\\rm cl})t]^{-1}\\}\\) (solid curve) with the fitted timing (tq) and duration (tq) of the resistance decrease caused by shape change.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG2.png: 'Figure 2: Modeling an elongating invagination with head-neck shape. We simulated elongation of the head-neck invagination described by \\(r_{\\text{neck}}/R_{\\text{head}}=0.1\\) using the following parameters: \\(P=9\\) atm, \\(t_{0}=\\) = 7 s (13 s into patch assembly), \\(\\tau=0.66\\) s, and \\(\\mu=0.08\\) nm/s/pN. Similar to experimental studies, the time here and below is offset by \\(-20\\) s so that the times of actin peaks would be around time zero. (A) The \\(\\{r,z\\}\\) sections of 3D distributions of actin densities (pseudocolors) and velocities (white arrows) are shown for three times: (left) beginning of elongation, (middle) actin half maximum, and (right) actin peak. Extracellular space is white; vertical dashed lines represent the axis of symmetry of model geometry. Velocity scale bars correspond to 60 nm/s. (B) Polymerized actin as a function of time. The numbers of subunits were counted inside a growing cylinder embedding the moving invagination: \\(r_{\\text{cyl}}=0.06\\)\\(\\mu\\)m, \\(z_{\\text{cyl}}=l+\\delta l+\\int_{t_{\\text{trap}}}^{t}u\\left(t^{\\prime}\\right) \\text{dt}^{\\prime}\\), where \\(t_{\\text{bagin}}\\) denotes the beginning of elongation and lengths are in \\(\\mu\\)m: the initial invagination length \\(l=0.07\\)\\(\\mu\\)m and short extra length \\(\\delta l=0.003\\)\\(\\mu\\)m. (C) Time dependence of driving force (solid curve) and resistance due to turgor pressure described by Eq (Z) (dashed curve); the invagination mobility used is \\(\\mu=0.08\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN. (D) Displacement is \\(\\sim\\)180 nm at the time actin peaks, which is thought to coincide with scission, yielding average elongation rate \\(\\sim\\)30 nm/s over the duration of elongation, \\(t_{\\text{scission}}=t_{\\text{bagin}}\\).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG3.png: 'Figure 3: Invaginations with “head-neck” shape have higher driving forces than cylindrical invaginations, yielding faster elongation and longer displacements. Dependence of (A) net driving force, \\(f_{\\mathrm{net}}=f_{\\mathrm{drive}}-f_{\\mathrm{wait}}\\), (B) elongation rates, and (C) displacements on the invagination geometry and \\(\\mu\\). The model was solved with the same parameters (with the exception of invagination mobility for the invagination with head-neck shape (\\(r_{\\mathrm{neck}}\\)/\\(R_{\\mathrm{head}}=0.1\\)) and mobility coefficients \\(\\mu=0.08\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN (solid curves) and \\(0.04\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN (dotted curves) and for the cylindrical invagination with \\(\\mu=0.08\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN (gray dashed curves) and \\(0.04\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN (black dashed curves). The head-neck invaginations began to move at \\(f_{\\mathrm{trap}}=-7\\) s, and the cylindrical invaginations started to elongate at \\(t_{\\mathrm{trap}}=-6.8\\) s. Vesicle scission, terminating elongation, is thought to occur when polymerized actin reaches its maximum. For the head-neck invaginations, \\(t_{\\mathrm{cstation}}=-0.8\\) s for \\(\\mu=0.08\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN and \\(-0.6\\) s for \\(\\mu=0.04\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN, and for the cylindrical invaginations, \\(t_{\\mathrm{cstation}}=0\\) s for \\(\\mu=0.04\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN and \\(0.9\\) s for \\(\\mu=0.08\\)\\(\\mu\\)m/s/pN. The displacements at \\(t_{\\mathrm{cstation}}\\) were 179 nm (solid curve), 153 nm (dotted curve), 64 nm (gray dashed curve), and 52 nm (black dashed curve).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG4.png: 'Figure 4: Output of simulations of models using optimized parameters for budding yeast (gray curves) and fission yeast (black curves). (A) Solid curves are \\(f_{\\rm drive}\\) (t); dashed curves are graphs of \\(f_{\\rm result}\\) (t), see Eq (2*); (B) net forces \\(f_{\\rm not}\\) (t) = \\(f_{\\rm drive}\\) (t) - \\(f_{\\rm result}\\) (t), with \\(f_{\\rm drive}\\) (t) and \\(f_{\\rm result}\\) (t) from (A); (C) displacements; (D) polymerized actin, with the maxima of 9826 subunits in fission yeast and S165 subunits in budding yeast. The budding yeast results are from the simulation with \\(f_{\\rm neck}\\)/\\(R_{\\rm head}\\) = 1/3. Values of \\(t_{0}\\) used in the simulations (Table 3) are "near-saturation" as evident from graphs in A. Simulated displacements (C) and elongations rates (Table 4) are in reasonable quantitative agreement with the experimental data in Sun et al. (2019). Results for polymerized actin in (D) predict that at scission, actin patches in budding yeast have fewer polymerized actin subunits than in fission yeast (see discussion in The model predicts that the peak numbers of actin are lower in budding yeast than fission yeast).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG5.png: 'FIGURE 5: Deriving the number of actin subunits in patches from simulated actin densities. We determined the number of actin subunits in a patch by integrating actin densities within a cylinder outlined in white, which elongates with the invagination (see Figure 2 legend). (A) Snapshot of actin densities (pseudocolors) at the time of peak actin (\\(\\tilde{\\epsilon}=1.9\\;s\\))\\({}_{r}\\) obtained with optimized parameters for fission yeast (Table 3). (B) Actin densities from A exceeding 6 mM: thresholding eliminates contributions from light-blue subspaces inside the box that may not be detected experimentally. (Vertical dashed lines represent the axis of symmetry of model geometry.)'
